awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: WAVES - A STEM-Powered Youth News Network for the Nation
awd_abstract_narration:
As a part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds research and innovative resources for use in a variety of settings. This media and technology project will scale up Youth Radio's proven model of STEM education through youth-driven multimedia journalism and related app development using the MIT App Inventor.   A new Youth News Network (YNN) will implement a nationwide feeder system of youth reporters and educators using the previously developed and proven STEM curriculum.  Previous research and evaluation has demonstrated that this model can engage underserved youth and put them in leadership positions in technological innovation.  Key deliverables include the YNN STEM Desk that will produce 15-20 STEM-related stories each year; bootcamps (1-3 day workshops) training youth around the country focusing on app development and media links; and new toolkits providing resources to help with app development, data analysis and other STEM-specific skills.  Project partners include MIT Media Lab, National Public Radio, Best Buy's Teen Tech Centers, National Writing Project, Computer Clubhouses, and PBS Learning Media among others.

Over the previous eight years, research and evaluation findings had been used to refine the project.  These data served as the foundation for this scale-up project. The research conducted by the investigator and the Scholar-in-Residence in this scale-up uses an embedded ethnographic approach that combines field notes, recorded meetings and discussions, media artifacts, etc.--data that is transcribed and coded for indicators of STEM learning and critical computational literacy.  The external summative evaluation will build on prior evidence regarding how this unique model engages youth and impacts their skills in STEM related media and technology.

por.por_cntn:
Through a one-of-a-kind partnership between YR Media and MIT App Inventor, the WAVES initiative broadened participation in STEM by unlocking robust learning pathways for thousands and partnering with them to reframe national conversations on key social issues related to science and technology in our lives.

The push to teach CS and programming has been taken up by politicians, non-profit leaders, school superintendents and CEOs seeking to democratize computing,equalize economic opportunity and ensure America’s worldwide competitiveness.  While we, too, are working to integrate the voices, perspectives, and experiences of historically marginalized communities into tech, we have found the dominant approach to be paradoxically problematic, at once misguidedly hopeful and not audacious enough. Education efforts designed to democratize participation in walled-off fields like science and technology tend to reduce them to the basics, making these disciplines more “accessible.” WAVES did the opposite. We expanded computational thinking into experiences of expression, imagination, and civic engagement. Grounded in the nation’s first and only coding program embedded inside a national youth-led newsroom, WAVES offers a model of youth-made media that is powered by technology, based in community, tethered to truth, and instrumental in giving young people especially those marginalized in the civic sphere a powerful say in the decisions that govern their lives.

YR Media established a national network for next-generation news and arts, by and for young people who are civically curious and culturally engaged from across America. Young people created 43 stories on STEM topics including: data and environmental science, AI and machine learning, and human development. In final year, YR Media’s content reached an audience of 5 million through our independent platform, launched in October 2018. Over the full lifecycle of WAVES, STEM stories were distributed through NPR, The New York Times, Teen Vogue, iTunes, Spotify and other leading outlets. Young people learned to tell stories “by any media necessary,” as Henry Jenkins has said, supported by YR Media’s editors and DIY resources. The range of products was diverse and boundary-breaking, including: print and radio features, web-based interactives, mobile apps, Q+As with thought-leaders, podcast episodes, videos, social media campaigns and interdisciplinary projects that invited communities to engage with content, driving conversation.

Through Youth Mobile Power initiative, YR Media and MIT App Inventor combined top-quality journalism with CS pedagogy to position young people as creators, not just consumers, of mobile technology. Youth Mobile Power highlighted the transformative potential young people hold in their hands when they use their phones to empower themselves and others and to create change they seek. We produced nine open-source App-Building guides, ranging from beginner to advanced. Each one starts with a YR Media story where a young person reports on an issue related to technology in our lives. The guide then walks users through a dynamic step-by-step tutorial for creating their own mobile app inspired by the story. MIT created new custom functionality within App Inventor, whose registered users now surpass 10 million worldwide, to support the Youth Mobile Power series and enhance users’ ability to create sophisticated apps. Youth Mobile Power App Building Guides have been accessed by more than 100,000 users to date a mix of developers and educators who are taking inspiration from youth stories to create mobile technology solutions while learning key computational thinking skills.

A high point of WAVES was our 2019 national challenge. We packaged nine YR Media stories from our newsroom as launch-pads for App Inventor community to create apps addressing issues raised by youth reporters. More than 30 teams participated from across the U.S., creating fully functioning apps and essays linking their technology to the stories. All submissions were assessed by a joint MIT/YR Media team of adult and youth judges, and winners were announced on YR Media, through local coverage,and live at 10th anniversary App Inventor Summit at MIT. 

Impact of WAVES expanded through bootcamps/workshops, including MIT Master Trainers Program in Mobile Computing, professional development program designed to grow global community of experts on mobile app development. These experts lead workshops in communities, schools and afterschool programs to empower teachers and students as they become mobile app designers,providing a pathway into CS, software development and other disciplines.

WAVES identified: 1. learning scaffolds that pique student curiosity about STEM and enable active investigation and production, 2. conditions that make STEM learning not just educative but also equitable and empowering, and 3. evidence that media creation can promote robust STEM learning. Through a mix of qualitative and quantitative methods and building on our concepts of Critical Computational Literacy and Collegial Pedagogy, we developed a new framework we call “Code for What?” We’ve presented our work at national and international conferences, through academic publications, and via a forthcoming book, a proposal for which was invited by MIT Press and is currently under review.
